Climate prediction will help with flood control and water resource management.

title: Advancing water quality monitoring through artificial neural networks: present insights and future opportunities in scientific exploration
abstract: The increasing demand for clean water resources and the challenges posed by rapid urbanization, industrialization, and climate change have intensified the need for effective water quality monitoring and management. This paper delves into the application of Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) as an innovative tool for assessing water quality, highlighting current issues and prospects for the development of scientific research. ANNs, with their inherent ability to learn complex patterns, offer a promising solution to address non-linear relationships between water quality parameters, allowing for accurate predictions and modeling. We provide an overview of the existing literature on ANN applications in water quality assessment and discuss the benefits and limitations of these models. Key factors contributing to the success of ANNs in this field include appropriate selection of input features, model architecture, and training methodologies. We also examine recent advancements in hybrid and deep learning models that can further improve the accuracy and efficiency of water quality predictions. The paper concludes by identifying potential areas for future research, such as the integration of remote sensing data, the implementation of real-time monitoring systems, and the development of decision support tools for water resource management. By fostering collaboration between researchers, engineers, and policymakers, we can harness the power of ANNs to safeguard our water resources and ensure sustainable development.

title: Prediction of groundwater fluctuations in Chengalpattu district through machine learning
abstract: Groundwater, found beneath the Earth’s surface in saturated zones of soil, sediment, and rock, plays a crucial role in sustaining ecosystems and supporting human activities like agriculture and industry. Monitoring and managing groundwater resources are crucial for sustainable use. As of the latest update in January 2022, Chennai, a city in southern India, has been grappling with water scarcity issues. The city has faced recurrent water shortages due to various factors, including rapid urbanization, inadequate infrastructure, depleting groundwater levels, and irregular rainfall patterns. Chengalpattu district in Tamil Nadu, India, is known for its diverse geographical features, incorporating urban and rural landscapes, and is significant for agriculture and water resource management. This study focuses on predicting variations in groundwater levels in open wells at different locations in the Chengalpattu district, assessing the effectiveness of various machine-learning models. This paper utilizes the ARIMA model provided by the stats models library. This library is widely employed for statistical modelling and hypothesis testing in Python, and encompasses a range of tools for time series analysis, including the ARIMA model. In this context. ARIMA models are employed for predicting future depth which focus on depicting autocorrelations in the data. Additionally, a package consolidating various models, including Seasonal Naïve (a straightforward forecasting method for seasonal data that serves as a reliable benchmark by relying on the observation from the same period a season ago), was incorporated in this study.

title: Use of Machine Learning and Indexing Techniques for Identifying Industrial Pollutant Sources: A Case Study of the Lower Kelani River Basin, Sri Lanka
abstract: With the recent acceleration in urbanisation and industrialisation, industrial pollution has severely impacted inland water bodies and ecosystem services globally, causing significant restrains to freshwater availability and myriad damages to benthic species. The Kelani River Basin in Sri Lanka, covering only ~3.6% of the land but hosting over a quarter of its population and many industrial zones, is identified as the most polluted watershed in the country. This study used unsupervised learning (UL) and an indexing approach to identify potential industrial pollutant sources along the Kelani River. The UL results were compared with those obtained from a novel Industrial Pollution Index (IPI). Three latent variables related to industrial pollution were identified via Factor Analysis of monthly water quality data from 17 monitoring stations from 2016 to 2020. The developed IPI was validated using a Long Short-Term Memory Artificial Neural Network model (NSE = 0.98, RMSE = 0.81), identifying Cd, Zn, and Fe as the primary parameters influencing river pollution status. The UL method identified five stations with elevated concentrations for the developed latent variables, and the IPI confirmed four of them. Based on the findings from both methods, the industrial zones along the Kelani River have emerged as a likely source of pollution in the river’s water. The results suggest that the proposed method effectively identifies industrial pollution sources, offering a scalable methodology for other river basins to ensure sustainable water resource management.

title: Development of a Multi-Scale Groundwater Drought Prediction Model Using Deep Learning and Hydrometeorological Data
abstract: Groundwater is an essential water resource and plays a crucial role, especially in areas with limited surface water availability. However, the exacerbation of groundwater droughts, fueled by phenomena such as climate change, urbanization, and industrialization, highlights the necessity for predictive tools to aid in sustainable groundwater management. While artificial neural networks (ANN) have been increasingly used for groundwater level prediction, most studies have focused solely on point-scale predictions from groundwater observation wells, which can be resource-intensive and time-consuming. In this study, we propose a multi-scale groundwater-based drought prediction model that can predict both zonal average values and the values at well locations for the standardized groundwater level index (SGI). Specifically, we develop a zone-scale SGI prediction model through long short-term memory (LSTM) and propose a model that can accurately predict point-scale SGI through a simple downscaling process. Our model was developed and tested for Jeju Island, a volcanic island in South Korea where groundwater serves as the primary water source. Specifically, we partitioned Jeju Island into 16 sub-watersheds, termed zones, and constructed an individual model for each zone. Forecasting the standardized groundwater level index (SGI) for each zone was based on input datasets including the daily temperature, precipitation, snowfall, vapor pressure deficit (VPD), wind speed, and preceding SGI values. Additionally, we downscaled the predicted values of each zone to the specific SGI values at groundwater monitoring wells within the zone. This was achieved by applying the spatial deviation of each well relative to the zonal mean over the preceding 4 days to the predicted zone-scale SGI value. Our findings indicate high accuracy of the model in SGI predictions across both scales, with the Nash–Sutcliffe efficiency coefficient (NSE) exceeding 0.9 and the root mean square error (RMSE) remaining less than 0.3 for both the representative zone and observation well. By leveraging the proposed model, stakeholders and policymakers can efficiently generate and utilize both zone-scale and point-scale groundwater-based drought predictions, contributing to effective groundwater management practices.

title: Trees, society, and the path toward resilient ecosystems
abstract: Over 3 trillion trees occupy the Earth's land surface, mostly in tropical and subtropical forests. These trees provide vital ecosystem services, such as climate regulation, carbon sequestration, and habitat and food provision. Trees are also deeply interconnected with humans, offering social and cultural values. The interdependence between trees and humans underlines the urgency to understand and protect trees in both natural and urban ecosystems amid climate change and other environmental pressures, including deforestation, land degradation, and pollution. This virtual issue examines five critical themes of trees and forests and their societal impact. Over 3 trillion trees occupy the Earth's land surface, mostly in tropical and subtropical forests (~1.3 trillion) (Crowther et al., 2015). These trees provide vital ecosystem services, such as climate regulation, carbon sequestration, and habitat and food provision (Brockerhoff et al., 2017; Myers, 1997). Trees are also deeply interconnected with humans, offering social and cultural values (O'Brien, 2005). The interdependence between trees and humans underlines the urgency to understand and protect trees in both natural and urban ecosystems amid climate change and other environmental pressures, including deforestation, land degradation, and pollution (De Marco et al., 2022; Esperon-Rodriguez, Tjoelker, et al., 2022; Kumar et al., 2022; Lindner et al., 2010). This virtual issue examines five critical themes of trees and forests and their societal impact. Each theme provides insights into cultural significance, ecosystem contributions, resilience and restoration, and technological innovations in conservation. In 'Climate Resilience and Adaptive Strategies of Trees', researchers investigate how trees adapt to climate change through resilience and genetic diversity with studies on urban forest adaptation, genetic variation, and seasonal responses of tree species. 'Forest Restoration and Biodiversity Conservation' shows strategies that enhance biodiversity and climate mitigation with diverse reforestation practices. In 'Trees and Human Culture', the research explores the cultural value of trees, focusing on the historical and societal importance of native and commercial species and their role in local traditions and economies. The authors of work featured in 'Trees as Ecosystem Engineers' highlight how trees contribute to biodiversity and support livelihoods, with studies on societal perceptions, species interactions, and endemic conservation efforts. Lastly, 'Technological Advances in Forest Monitoring and Conservation' delves into tools like UAVs and genetic analyses that aid in monitoring and preserving forests. Together, these themes offer a comprehensive view of trees' essential roles across ecosystems, human culture, and emerging conservation efforts. As a response to climate change and urbanization, researchers highlight the need to enhance urban forest resilience. Urban forests, essential for decreasing urban heat and improving air quality and human well-being (Keeler et al., 2019), face risks from climate-induced stress. To secure the provision of these benefits to urban residents, Esperon-Rodriguez, Rymer, et al. (2022) emphasize the importance of selecting tree species suited to the projected climate conditions in cities along with other desirable characteristics, such as aesthetic value and biodiversity support. By assessing the risks to heat, drought, and pest outbreaks, urban planners can make informed decisions to increase the longevity of urban trees and secure the services they provide (Esperon-Rodriguez, Rymer, et al., 2022). Urban environments present unique challenges and opportunities for tree resilience. Sjöman et al. (2024) examined how genetic diversity within tree species (i.e., intraspecific variation) supports resilience to urban stresses, such as pollution and limited water availability. The authors suggest that by focusing on resilient tree varieties, urban forestry initiatives can improve biodiversity and ecosystem function within cities, fostering healthier urban landscapes that also contribute to climate resilience. Species, however, respond differently to local environmental conditions. For example, Goessen et al. (2022) explored how tree species have diverse adaptations driven by geographic conditions. Their study focused on Populus tremuloides, or Quaking aspen, a species native to North America, has developed divergent strategies in response to local environmental constraints, reflecting the role of genetic diversity in resilience. In Japan, Miyawaki-Kuwakado et al. (2024) investigated how warming temperatures affect the timing of seasonal events like bud dormancy. Their research on the iconic Yoshino cherry tree (Cerasus × yedoensis) showed that climate change may lead to mistimed flowering. Such shifts threaten species reliant on specific climatic triggers, raising concerns about the long-term viability of temperature-sensitive species in changing climates. Importantly, these changes can also have socio-economic disruptions, as the blossoming of cherries is an important tourism resource (Murata et al., 2012). Similar results were found in the Singapore Botanic Gardens, where Ho et al. (2024) conducted a long-term assessment of changes in leafing behavior of tropical trees in response to climate change. They found that tropical trees can adjust their leafing behavior over extended periods, showcasing their adaptive capacity. By focusing on adaptive capacity, genetic diversity, and optimal species selection, this research offers pathways to enhance forest resilience and sustain the ecological and social benefits that trees provide. Forest restoration plays a critical role in climate change mitigation and biodiversity conservation as global efforts aim to reverse deforestation and land degradation (Bastin et al., 2019). Andres et al. (2023) sought to define the term "biodiverse reforestation" and explained why this matters for climate change mitigation and biodiversity. The authors emphasize the importance of integrating biodiversity goals into reforestation efforts. By prioritizing species diversity, reforestation projects can sequester carbon more effectively while supporting ecosystem functions and species. This represents a more resilient and sustainable approach to forest restoration. Importantly, the authors consider the potential for improving scientific approaches to biodiverse reforestation with First Nations perspectives. The co-benefits of Indigenous knowledge and values have been recognized as vital to climate adaptation (Nursey-Bray et al., 2022). In restoration, ensuring water efficiency in seedlings is crucial, especially under climate stress. Krishnan et al. (2023) examined how organic nitrogen can enhance water-use efficiency in tropical tree seedlings. They showed that nutrient addition allowed seedlings to establish more effectively under dry conditions, suggesting practical strategies for forest restoration projects in arid regions. This has important repercussions not only for restoration but also for food production. For example, in regions where food security and forest health are closely linked, selecting appropriate tree species is essential. A study in Burkina Faso, West Africa, by Vinceti et al. (2022) explored how tree species contribute to both ecological restoration and local nutrition. By including species that provide food, like fruit-bearing trees, reforestation initiatives in Burkina Faso can address both environmental and community needs, creating landscapes that support biodiversity while improving food security. Local and small-scale efforts, such as home gardens, also play a significant role in supporting biodiversity and for conservation. Offord and Zimmer (2024) studied how home gardeners help preserve the critically endangered Wollemi Pine (Wollemia nobilis). This species native to Australia was described as new to science in 1994 and is represented by fewer than 100 individuals (Trueman et al., 2007). By cultivating Wollemi Pine in private gardens, individuals contribute to broader conservation goals, ensuring genetic diversity and supporting efforts to reintroduce the species into its natural habitat (Offord & Zimmer, 2024). This approach highlights the value of community-based conservation in supporting endangered species and enhancing biodiversity. Trees and forests have profound cultural and economic value, reflecting centuries of human interaction and local knowledge (O'Brien, 2005). Recent research investigates the cultural, economic, and social significance of tree species, focusing on the importance of identity, naming, and preservation of species. Dunbar-Wallis et al. (2023) highlight the significance of preserving historic North American apple (Malus domestica) varieties. Their study showed how naming and identifying these apples maintain cultural heritage and biodiversity. North American apples represent historical practices and tastes, underscoring the importance of preserving these genetic resources as part of local identity and resilience. Notably, M. domestica is one of the most cultivated fruits worldwide (ranked fourth) with an average annual production of over 85 million tons globally (FAOSTAT, 2020). For the wild apple (Malus sylvestris), Ruhsam et al. (2023) took the challenge of accurately identifying the nursery stock sold in nurseries from the United Kingdom. Wild apple species are vital for genetic diversity and resilience, and ensuring authenticity in nursery stock is crucial for conservation. This research highlights the importance of preserving genetic integrity and maintaining access to wild species, which are valuable for both biodiversity and cultural heritage. Studying a culturally significant species, the barnī date palm variety, a local elite variety of al-'Ulā oasis in Saudi Arabia, Gros-Balthazard et al. (2023) found that this variety is not only an economic staple but also a cultural icon in the region. Through its name and cultivation, the barnī date palm represents a rich heritage that has sustained communities for generations, illustrating how plant varieties can embody place-based knowledge and cultural ties. In a similar study, Gurung et al. (2024) explored the cultural and medicinal significance of Buddleja asiatica, a shrub native to the East Indies. In the Pan-Himalayan region, this species is integral to local healthcare practices, providing essential medicinal benefits to communities. Its use reflects a traditional knowledge system and highlights the symbiotic relationship between people and native plant species, demonstrating the role of trees in supporting cultural identity and local health. Trees as ecosystem engineers (i.e., organisms responsible for the creation and maintenance of habitats; Jones et al., 1996) can change the abiotic context upon which biotic interactions depend (Byers et al., 2006). Thus, community livelihoods rely on identifying threats and benefits provided by trees. Tsvuura et al. (2023) explored gender perspectives on the perceived benefits and threats of tree restoration in South Africa. They explored how communities view trees as valuable contributors to their livelihoods, recognizing the critical role trees play in providing resources such as timber, fruit, and medicinal products. However, this study also highlights concerns regarding threats to these benefits, such as climate change, deforestation, and urbanization. These threats challenge the sustainability of the services that communities depend on, underscoring the need for strategies that secure tree resources while balancing conservation and economic needs (Sivakumar et al., 2024). In Yemen, Maděra et al. (2024) studied 11 endemic frankincense tree (Boswellia) taxa in the Socotra Archipelago. These species are culturally and economically valuable to local communities. However, frankincense trees are also threatened by overharvesting, habitat loss, and climate change, threatening local biodiversity and the communities reliant on them for livelihood. Maděra et al.'s study provides a detailed ecological assessment identifying regions at most risk and offers insights into conservation strategies that balance sustainable use with the preservation of genetic diversity. The conservation of frankincense trees is critical not only for the ecosystem but also for supporting traditional practices and economic stability for people in the region. As hosts for other species, trees can develop complex interactions, such as the relationship between strangler figs and their host trees, studied by Mo et al. (2024). Strangler figs start life on host trees, gradually growing and often overtaking the host tree's structure. While this interaction may seem parasitic, it can enhance urban green spaces by adding unique biodiversity and aesthetic value. This study suggests that, when managed properly, strangler figs can enrich urban ecosystems by creating microhabitats for multiple species, supporting urban biodiversity, and improving the resilience of green spaces (Mo et al., 2024). This research highlights the dual ecological and cultural significance of these trees in urban landscapes. Modern technologies like AI, UAVs (unmanned aerial vehicles), and genetic tools are shaping a new era in the conservation, management, and monitoring of forests worldwide. By combining UAV surveys, genetic analysis, advanced forestry tools, and ground-based monitoring, researchers and managers can make informed decisions about forest conservation and sustainable use. These technologies not only improve our understanding of forest ecosystems but also facilitate enforcing regulations, planning conservation strategies, and adapting to climate change impacts on forests. In Madagascar, Williams (2024) used UAVs to monitor deforestation in real-time. Madagascar harbors a unique biodiversity, but this is threatened by illegal logging (Ralimanana et al., 2022). UAVs enable rapid, cost-effective detection of deforestation, offering precise data on forest loss and allowing authorities to respond promptly to illegal activities (Williams, 2024). In a global review of emerging tools to support sustainable forestry, Bunney et al. (2023) focused on protecting sandalwood species (a variety of species in the family Santalaceae), which are culturally and economically valuable and threatened by overharvesting. This review examined different methods, including DNA barcoding, to verify the species of harvested wood and remote sensing for forest monitoring. Together, these studies demonstrate the importance of combining drones, remote sensing, and genetic tools for comprehensive forest conservation strategies. The role of genomics in understanding the resilience of tree species was studied by Kong et al. (2023). Prosopis alba, native to arid environments, possesses genetic traits that allow it to withstand extreme drought and saline conditions. By mapping the genome of P. alba, Kong et al. demonstrated species adaptability, which can inform breeding programs aimed at enhancing the resilience of trees in regions facing water scarcity and climate stress. Genomic tools enable targeted conservation of tree species that are vital to ecosystem stability in extreme climates (Isabel et al., 2020). Finally, in a study using ground-based data, Anderson-Teixeira et al. (2024) showed that effective forest carbon inventories require precise measurements of carbon stocks. Technologies such as remote sensing paired with field data can provide reliable estimates. This approach enhances the accuracy of reporting forest carbon, helping countries meet their climate goals and track the effectiveness of conservation efforts. Collectively, these studies show the essential roles that trees play in both natural and urban environments, particularly in the face of climate change and environmental pressures. They reveal how trees adapt to climate changes, underscoring the importance of genetic diversity and adaptive strategies to strengthen climate-resilient forestry. This knowledge supports informed species selection and management to foster resilient forests that benefit both ecosystems and communities. A multi-faceted approach to forest restoration, one that incorporates ecological, cultural, and social factors, emerges as crucial for sustaining biodiversity while meeting community needs. These studies highlight trees as cultural symbols and economic resources, essential for preserving cultural identity and biodiversity. Trees also serve as ecosystem engineers, offering ecosystem services that support biodiversity, air quality, and water regulation, while facing significant threats from human impact. Notably, technological advancements and emerging tools are transforming forest conservation and monitoring, providing researchers with tools to better protect and manage forest ecosystems. Together, these studies provide insights and innovations toward more sustainable and resilient ecosystems that benefit both the environment and society. MER wrote this article. MER received fundings from Research Theme Program from Western Sydney University. No conflict of interest is declared. Data sharing is not applicable to this article as no new data were created or analyzed in this study.

title: The limitation of machine learning methods for water supply and demand forecasting: A case study for Greater Melbourne, Australia
abstract: ABSTRACT Many cities around the world have faced water scarcity due to climate change, population growth, and urbanization. Accurate water supply and demand forecasting is critical for sustainable urban water management. Machine learning (ML) models provide new possibilities for forecasting compared with traditional models in handling non-linearity. This study aims to address the efficacy of ML models, long short-term memory (LSTM), stacked LSTM, bidirectional LSTM (Bi-LSTM), and multilayer perceptron (MLP), for forecasting water supply and demand in Greater Melbourne, Australia. The ML modelling utilized daily water supply and demand, and climatic variables (rainfall and maximum temperature) recorded by Melbourne Water and the Bureau of Meteorology from 1990 to 2019. The stacked LSTM performs better than other models in forecasting with R2, RMSE, and MAPE values of 0.908, 335.74 ML, and 23.5% for water supply and 0.791, 94.88 ML, and 5.3% for water demand, respectively. The inclusion of climatic variables enhanced the accuracy of forecasting by improving R2 and reducing RMSE and MAPE. The results indicate effectiveness of ML models, particularly LSTM-based architectures, in forecasting water supply and demand. However, these models have limitations, particularly in forecasting extreme values, emphasizing the need to improve ML models for more reliable and accurate water management.

title: Analogue and Physical Reservoir Computing Using Water Waves
abstract: More than 3.5 billion people live in rural areas, where water and water energy resources play an important role in ensuring sustainable and productive rural economies. This article reviews and critically analyses the recent advances in the field of analogue and reservoir computing that have been driven by unique physical properties and energy of water waves. It also demonstrates that analogue and reservoir computing hold the potential to bring artificial intelligence closer to people living outside large cities, thus enabling them to enjoy the benefits of novel technologies that already work in large cities but are not readily available and suitable for regional communities.

title: Water Use Attribution Analysis and Prediction Based on the VIKOR Method and Grey Neural Network Model: A Case Study of Zhangye City
abstract: Water consumption forecasting is a critical aspect of the increasingly strained water resources and sustainable water management processes. It is essential to explore the current status of water use patterns and future development directions in Zhangye City. In this study, 17 factors affecting water consumption in Zhangye City were selected to analyze changes in water consumption and to predict values from 2003 to 2022, utilizing the entropy weight–VIKOR model and the grey neural network model. The results indicate that agricultural water consumption and annual rainfall are the factors with the largest weights among the social and natural attribute indicators, respectively, significantly influencing water consumption in Zhangye City. As the proportions of water consumption for forestry, animal husbandry, fishery, livestock, urban public use, and ecological environment increase, while agricultural water consumption continues to decline, the overall water consumption trend in Zhangye City from 2003 to 2022 shows a positive trajectory. Each water consumption factor is tending toward greater balance, and the relationship between water supply and distribution is improving. The multi-year average relative error of the water consumption predictions for Zhangye City from 2003 to 2022 using the grey neural network model was 4.28%. Furthermore, the relative error values for annual predictions ranged from 0.60% to 5.00%, achieving an accuracy rate of 80.00%. This indicates a strong predictive performance. Ultimately, the model was used to predict a water consumption of 20.18 × 108 m3 in Zhangye City in 2027. The model can serve as a theoretical reference for short-term water consumption forecasting and for establishing a basin water resource allocation system in Zhangye City.

title: Cutting-Edge Techniques in Hydrology: Modeling Water Systems and Mitigating Flood Risks
abstract: Abstract This chapter delves into the latest advancements in hydrological modeling and flood risk management, emphasizing innovative techniques for understanding and managing water systems. It explores a range of hydrological modeling approaches, including rainfall-runoff models, hydrodynamic models, and groundwater models, highlighting their applications in simulating water flow and predicting flood risks. The chapter also covers cutting-edge forecasting methods such as machine learning, remote sensing, and data assimilation, which enhance the accuracy of flood predictions. Through case studies and practical examples, the chapter illustrates the application of these techniques in managing urban flooding, river basin systems, and the impacts of climate change. The conclusion emphasizes the importance of integrating multidisciplinary data and collaboration in developing resilient flood risk management strategies. Keywords: Hydrological modeling, flood risk management, rainfall-runoff models, hydrodynamic models, groundwater models, machine learning, remote sensing, data assimilation, urban flooding, river basin management, climate change adaptation, multidisciplinary data integration, resilient infrastructure, global collaboration.

title: IoT-Based Water Quality Monitoring and Remote Pipeline Surveillance System
abstract: By incorporating cutting-edge technologies for more robust, sustainable, and effective urban water systems, a smart water grid revolutionizes the management of water resources. The main goals, elements, advantages, and difficulties of smart water networks are covered in this synopsis. These grids maximize water supply, minimize waste, and manage environmental consequences through the use of sensors, real-time analytics, and networked infrastructure. AI, IoT devices, sensor networks, data analytics, and remote monitoring are some of the components. Proactive leak detection, water conservation, and enhanced resource management are made possible by the system. Although they come with drawbacks like exorbitant costs and worries about data security, smart water networks can improve climate resilience, facilitate demand forecasting, and engage customers.

title: A deep learning model for real-time forecasting of 2-D river flood inundation maps
abstract: Abstract. Floods are among the most hazardous natural disasters worldwide. Accurate and rapid flood predictions are critical for effective early warning systems and flood management strategies. The high computational cost of hydrodynamic models often limits their application in real-time flood simulations. Conversely, data-driven models are gaining attention due to their high computational efficiency. In this study, we aim at assessing the effectiveness of transformer-based models for forecasting the spatiotemporal evolution of fluvial floods in real-time. To this end, the transformer-based data-driven model FloodSformer (FS) has been adapted to predict river flood inundations with negligible computational time. The FS model leverages an autoencoder framework to analyze and reduce the dimensionality of spatial information in input water depth maps, while a transformer architecture captures spatiotemporal correlations between inundation maps and inflow discharges using a cross-attention mechanism. The trained model can predict long-lasting events using an autoregressive procedure. The model's performance was evaluated in two case studies: an urban flash flood scenario at the laboratory scale and a river flood scenario along a segment of the Po River (Italy). Datasets were numerically generated using a two-dimensional hydrodynamic model. Special attention was given to analyzing how the accuracy of predictions is influenced by the type and severity of flood events used to create the training dataset. The results show that prediction errors generally align with the uncertainty observed in physically based models, and that larger and more diverse training datasets help improving the model's accuracy. Additionally, the computational time of the real-time forecasting procedure is negligible compared to the physical time of the simulated event. The performance of the FS model was also benchmarked against a state-of-the-art convolutional neural network architecture and showed better accuracy. These findings highlight the potential of transformer-based models in enhancing flood prediction accuracy and responsiveness, contributing to improve flood management and resilience.

title: Statistical Analysis and Prediction via Neural Networks of water quality in the Middle Paraíba do Sul (Rio de Janeiro State, Brazil) region in the period (2012 - 2022)
abstract: <title>Abstract</title> This study presents a 10-year temporal assessment (2012–2022) of water quality in the Middle Paraíba do Sul hydrographic region, using the Water Quality Index (WQI) and statistical tools, with predictions via General Regression Neural Network (GRNN). The analysis, based on INEA data, highlights climatic events such as the 2014/2015 drought and differences between the WQI in rainy and dry seasons. The preservation of water quality in this region is crucial for public health, sustainability, and the economic development of the Rio de Janeiro metropolitan area, which relies on the Paraíba do Sul River. Increasing urbanization, agricultural expansion, and climate change pose challenges to water quality. Statistical tools such as Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) reveal significant variations between monitoring points, and GRNN predicts WQI trends for 2023. This predictive approach is vital for informed decision-making in water resource management, particularly as environmental pressures increase.

title: Integrating Machine Learning, Land Cover, and Hydrological Modeling to Contribute Parameters for Climate Impacts on Water Resource Management
abstract: The purpose of this study is to establish basic policies for managing the impacts of climate change on water resources using the integration of machine learning and land cover modeling. We predicted future changes in land cover within the water management and assessed its vulnerability to climate change. After confirming this vulnerability, we considered measures to improve climate resilience and presented future water resource parameters. We reviewed the finances available to promote climate projects, noting the major river management funds. The future project will serve as a stepping stone to promote climate resilience projects addressing water resource challenges exacerbated by future climate change. The study examined the results of analyzing changes in land cover maps due to climate change and assessed vulnerability in water management areas until 2050. According to the analysis results, the regulations for our study areas were set lower than those for other water management zones, resulting in a high rate of urbanization. Therefore, the climate resilience project in the water management area should be implemented first, despite the need for a long-term view in adapting to climate change.

title: Predicting river water quality under different environmental factors and its significance with Machine Learning approach
abstract: River Water Quality (RWQ) is significantly influenced by natural and anthropogenic activities such as land use and land cover changes. Urbanization has led to an increase in impervious surfaces, which alters hydrological flow pattern and delivers non-point pollutants to the stream more efficiently. In addition, intensification of agricultural activities can result in the increased nutrient loads due to alternations in surface soil properties. Hence, it is necessary to understand the impact of surrounding environment with specific emphasis on geographical factors (e.g. climate change, land use patterns and landscape metrics) on the RWQ in order to develop sustainable water quality management strategies effectively. We collected pollutant concentration Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD), Total Phosphorus (T-P), and&#160; Total Organic Carbon(TOC) from monitoring stations in the Nakdong River watershed. To utilize field monitoring data, we developed a Machine Learning (ML) models (DNN, XGBoost and Random Forest) to predict RWQ in accordance with different environmental factors. SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) was used to illustrate the significance of land uses and landscape patterns on RWQ in Nakdong River. The results of this study can (1) demonstrate the relationship of water quality variables with land uses and landscape patterns, (2) identify pollution sources and factors that affect Nakdong River, and (3) support catchment managers and stakeholders in evaluating the benefits and risks of water management strategies in priority areas.

title: Effects of Long-Term Wetland Variations on Flood Risks in the Yangtze River Basin&#160;
abstract: In the Yangtze River Basin (YRB), flooding is the most frequent natural disaster with enormous socio-economic damages. As a critical component in the hydrological cycle, the wetlands along the YRB have been changing during recent decades because of urbanization, intensive farming (e.g., aquaculture and agriculture) and climate change. Due to the lack of a long-term wetland classification dataset with comprehensive wetland categories, however, there&#8217;s a noticeable gap in the YRB water management regarding the relative roles of different wetland categories on flood resilience. Therefore, this study aimed to generate a long-term wetland classification dataset for the YRB and further investigate the long-term wetland variations on the YRB flood risk assessments for the period from 1985 to 2021. The dataset named Long-Term Wetland Classification Dataset for YRB (LTWCD_YRB) was created using a Random Forest machine learning classifier on Google Earth Engine with 30m resolution Landsat 5, 7, 8 muti-spectral images. The maps of LTWCD_YRB demonstrated the spatial distribution, annual variability, and seasonal cycle of nine wetland categories in the extent, and the total validation accuracy can reach 85%. The LTWCD_YRB indicated that the total wetland area of the YRB in 2021 was larger than that in 1985, with constantly increased human-made wetlands and fluctuated natural wetlands. Aquaculture ponds expanded the most (4,987 km2);&#160;inland marsh in the source region was the wetland category with the most fluctuations. Seasonal changes in wetlands were prominent in the Poyang Lake Basin, Dongting Lake Basin, and YRB source region. The LTWCD_YRB&#160;can offer a consistent agreement of wetland area variations with the other satellite-based wetland datasets in the YRB, which is&#160;valuable for researchers&#160;and stakeholders to better understand the YRB wetlands and would support sustainable wetland management practices.&#160;With the&#160;LTWCD_YRB data as modelling inputs, a GIS-based spatial multi-index&#160;flooding risk assessment model was applied for investigating&#160;the long-term implications of wetland variations on flood risks in the YRB. The model results indicate that in the year with large floods and extremely high precipitation, flood risk level increased obviously after adding the wetland factor. For the years with normal precipitation, flood risk level decreased with wetlands expansion and increased with wetlands shrinkage in the YRB. The long-term expansion of aquaculture ponds contributed to a lower flood risk in the Taihu Lake Basin. In contrast, the Poyang Lake Basin experienced an increasing flood risk due to the long-term shrinkage in lake areas resulting from soil erosion and urbanization along the lakeside. This study would be helpful&#160;for stakeholders to develop feasible wetland management practices, and to improve flood risk resilience in the YRB.

title: Drought dynamics in mixed climate regions: insights for water resource management and climate adaptation strategies
abstract: <title>Abstract</title> Global warming and climate change are causing temperatures to rise, which is having a negative impact on water resources. Climate change is a worldwide problem that affects and will continue to affect the frequency and intensity of natural disasters in many regions of the world. Tunceli region in Turkey, which until ten years ago was known as an environmentally friendly city with abundant water resources and frequent rainfall, is experiencing a decrease in precipitation during the snowy winter season. This situation has made the investigation of climate change impacts an important issue in the region. Therefore, effective climate change adaptation strategies need to be developed. To determine these strategies, in this study, we assessed drought conditions using drought indices such as Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI), Reconnaissance Drought Index (RDI), Normal Precipitation Index (PNI), and Aridity Index (AI). The SPI and RDI analyses were performed in annual reference periods on a time scale of 3, 6, 9, and 12 months using temperature, precipitation, and evaporation data. Consequently, the SPI and RDI results were compared, and both indices show similar behavior in dry, wet, and normal seasons. Nevertheless, RDI shows less variation between different time scales, which is an advantage over SPI and is probably due to the inclusion of potential evapotranspiration in RDI. The variations in PNI between humid and dry sub-humid categorizations throughout the years, combined with the AI results, indicate that the Tunceli region predominantly experiences a climate ranging from dry sub-humid to semi-arid. This study could help decision-makers take effective measures to become more resilient to climate change in temperate climate regions and take important steps toward sustainable water resources management.

title: Modeling the impact of climate and land use changes on future water resources dynamics in central Sicily, Italy
abstract: Drought events, worsened by climate change, produce detrimental impacts on freshwater availability especially in arid and semi-arid regions. The situation becomes more critical when these hydrologic extremes combine with land use change mainly caused by anthropogenic factors, such as urbanization, intensive farming, and industrial activities. The present study is designed to investigate the combined impacts of climate and land use changes on the future freshwater &#160;stored in the artificial reservoirs of three adjacent river basins located in the central Sicily (Italy), i.e: Verdura (2 active reservoirs with capacities 9.2 Mmc and 4.19 Mmc), Imera Meridionale (one active reservoir with capacity 15 Mmc), and Platani (one active reservoir with capacity 20.7Mmc), using the Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT) model. The reservoirs are used for irrigation, drinking water supply, and electric power generation. Future climate variables such as rainfall, minimum and maximum temperatures were derived from an ensemble Regional Climate Models for two main representative concentration pathway (RCP) scenarios, such as an intermediate emission scenario (RCP4.5) and a severe emission scenario (RCP8.5). A coupled multi-layer perceptron neural networks and cellular automata (MLP-CA) model was implemented to simulate future land use of the region considering the CORINE land cover in 2000, 2006, 2012, and 2018 as a reference dataset. The future land use is then projected until the mid-century (2048) in a six-year interval using the validated MLP-CA model. The soil data from the European soil data center (EUSDAC) was used as input for the SWAT model. The result indicated that the basins could experience a decrease in inflows to the reservoirs. The separate evaluation of climate change and land use changes indicated that the effect of climate change on streamflow variation is more pronounced than the effect of land use change only. In this study, we introduced new hydrological insights into the region by analyzing the attributions of climate change, land use change, and coupled climate and land use changes on the future freshwater availability which were overlooked in the previous studies. The implementation of the proposed approach can contribute to design environmentally sustainable and climate resilient river basin management strategies. &#160; Keywords: MLP-CA, Land use change, Climate change, SWAT, Hydrological modeling, Water availability

title: Data-driven modeling of municipal water system responses to hydroclimate extremes
abstract: Abstract Sustainable western US municipal water system (MWS) management depends on quantifying the impacts of supply and demand dynamics on system infrastructure reliability and vulnerability. Systems modeling can replicate the interactions but extensive parameterization, high complexity, and long development cycles present barriers to widespread adoption. To address these challenges, we develop the Machine Learning Water Systems Model (ML-WSM) – a novel application of data-driven modeling for MWS management. We apply the ML-WSM framework to the Salt Lake City, Utah water system, where we benchmark prediction performance on the seasonal response of reservoir levels, groundwater withdrawal, and imported water requests to climate anomalies at a daily resolution against an existing systems model. The ML-WSM accurately predicts the seasonal dynamics of all components; especially during supply-limiting conditions (KGE &gt; 0.88, PBias &lt; ±3%). Extreme wet conditions challenged model skill but the ML-WSM communicated the appropriate seasonal trends and relationships to component thresholds (e.g., reservoir dead pool). The model correctly classified nearly all instances of vulnerability (83%) and peak severity (100%), encouraging its use as a guidance tool that complements systems models for evaluating the influences of climate on MWS performance.

title: Hybrid Drought Forecasting Framework for Water‐Scarce Regions Based on Support Vector Machine and Precipitation Index
abstract: ABSTRACT Drought is a natural event that slowly deteriorates water reserves. This study aims to develop a machine learning–based computational framework for monitoring drought status in water‐scarce regions. The proposed framework integrates the precipitation index (PI) with support vector machine models to forecast drought occurrences based on an autoregressive modelling scheme. Due to the suitability of the PI for drought analysis in arid climates, the developed hybrid model is appropriate in regions with limited rainfall. This study used a historical precipitation dataset from 1958 to 2020 at the Kuwait International Airport, Kuwait City. The study area is characterised by scarce rainfall and is vulnerable to severe water shortages owing to limited water resources. Initially, historical PI time‐series datasets were examined for stationarity to validate the utility of the autoregressive model. The autocorrelation function test was significantly associated with the PI time series at the 12‐ and 24‐month drought‐monitoring scales. Predictive drought forecasting models were constructed to predict drought occurrences up to 3 months in advance. Statistical evaluation metrics were used to assess model performance for the 12‐ and 24‐month drought‐monitoring scales. The results showed a strong association between the observed and predicted drought events, with coefficients of determination ( R 2 ) ranging between 0.865 and 0.925 for the 12‐ and 24‐month drought‐monitoring scales. The proposed computational framework aims to provide water managers in arid and water‐scarce regions with efficient and reliable drought‐monitoring tools to assist in preparing appropriate water management plans. This study provides guidance for improving water resource resilience under water shortage scenarios in the study area and other climatic regions by applying suitable drought indices in conjunction with robust data‐driven models. The results provide a baseline for water resource policymakers worldwide to establish sustainable water conservation strategies and provide crucial insights for drought disaster preparation.

title: Assessing Future hydrological response of an urban watershed using machine learning based LULC forecasting models
abstract: Urbanization in terms of land-use/cover (LULC) change has a long-term significant impact on the hydrological cycle as the LULC is one of the most important influencing parameters to produce curve number (CN). The drastic change in LULC changes the CN. This change directly affects surface water including peak flows. This study aims to assess the change in surface runoff due to changes in LULC. Hydrological modeling is done for the consistent long-term behavioral study of surface runoff. The area focused on the study is the Kharun river, a tributary of the Mahanadi River. For the assessment of the impact of LULC change on the catchment discharge, a daily-step conceptual model soil and water assessment tool (SWAT) was applied. Landuse maps were prepared with the Landsat Thematic Mapper satellite images. The future land use was forecasted with the technique of spatial statistical modeling. The machine learning (ML) tool is used for quantifying the influences on the LULC change dynamics and producing the LULC map for 2024 and 2030. Remote sensing (RS) and geographic information system (GIS) analysis were coupled with hydrological SWAT modeling to investigate the connection between the LULC change and hydrologic regime. The SWAT Model’s calibration efficiency is verified by comparing the simulated and observed discharge time series at the Patharidih gauge and discharge station. The monthly and daily calibrations were quite satisfactory, with Nash-Sutcliffe an efficiency coefficient of 0.86 and 0.67. This modeling provides reliable information for sustainable management of available water resources of the catchment.

title: Monitoring Coastline Dynamics Using Satellite Remote Sensing and Geographic Information Systems: A Review of Global Trends
abstract: Nearly half of the world's population lives near the coasts of oceans and seas. The coastline position changes under the influence of multiple natural and anthropogenic factors. Recently, due to the global impacts of climate change and population growth, the issue of geomorphological changes in coastlines has become more critical. Therefore, the assessment and mapping of coastline dynamics is one of the most essential factors for sustainable development goals and urban planning. The objectives of this study are to focus on discussing the research progress of applications of satellite remote sensing datasets and GIS methods for coastline extraction, mapping, and analysis along global coasts. A systematic review and trend analysis of the most recent published studies that focused on remote sensing and GIS techniques for assessing coastal dynamics were published between 2012 and 2022 along different coasts worldwide. The results indicated that multisource and multisensor remote sensing datasets were globally utilized for monitoring coastline changes, including (1) medium-resolution imagery such as Sentinel and Landsat, (2) SAR and optical high-resolution imagery, (3) modern remote sensing technologies such as UAV and LiDAR, and (4) GIS-based methods, spatial analysis, and artificial intelligence. This study concludes that coastal change can be tracked using any form of remote sensing, including drones, LiDAR, higher resolution imaging, and Landsat imagery. This review provides a comprehensive reference for upcoming work on coastal management and exploitation development and research, especially for the low elevation coastal zones that are affected by coastal hazards.

title: Recent advancements in aquaponics with special emphasis on its sustainability
abstract: Abstract An aquaponic system which is an integration of hydroponics with aquaculture is sustainable, ecologically friendly, and uses non‐renewable resources with very high efficacy. The increasing trend in aquaponics research demonstrates a growing recognition of its potential to address critical global issues such as food security, water conservation, and sustainable agriculture, particularly in regions vulnerable to climate change and resource limitations. It has witnessed remarkable advancements in recent years, with various methods and variations emerging to enhance its functionality and productivity. The purpose of this review is to unify fragmented research on aquaponics and provide a comprehensive resource that emphasizes its potential for broad adoption and successful implementation in varied environments. This review focuses on recent innovations in aquaponic system designs for various climates and examines key advancements in critical areas, including microbial communities, biofiltration, feed management, water quality, and nutrient cycling, emphasizing the interdisciplinary nature of aquaponics. Coupled systems suit moderate climates with high resource efficiency, while decoupled systems offer flexibility across diverse climates by allowing independent control of each component. Innovations such as sandponics, algaeponics, and saline aquaponics address challenges like water scarcity and nutrient efficiency. Smart technologies like IoT and AI are integrated into aquaponics, automating monitoring and nutrient management for better productivity. Emerging areas, including vermi‐aquaponics and flocponics, offer new solutions for nutrient cycling, making aquaponics more efficient, adaptable, and resource‐conserving globally. This paper also examines the sustainability aspects of aquaponics, emphasizing its economic, social, and environmental dimensions. Despite high setup costs and nutrient complexities, aquaponics offers significant potential for sustainable food production by minimizing water use and reducing synthetic fertilizers. Its scalability in both urban and rural areas, along with innovations like vertical systems, presents promising solutions for enhancing agriculture and food security across diverse environments.

title: Ecology of Lake Erie - Nutrients, microbes, algae, and dreissenid mussels: A synthesis
abstract: The Lake Erie ecosystem, including its physical, chemical, and biological components, has changed considerably during recent decades owing to human-induced environmental stress (Fraker et al., 2022; Makarewicz and Bertram, 1991; Munawar and Munawar, 1976; Sinclair et al., 2021). While much has been learned from monitoring and research activities, a full understanding of how and why the ecosystem has changed is lacking (Fraker et al., 2023; Fussell et al., 2016; Sterner et al., 2017; Scavia et al., 2023), which has hampered the development of management strategies that can help sustain the integrity of the lake and its valued ecosystem services (e.g. clean water, safe recreation, food production). This AEHM special issue is the first of four focused on Lake Erie, all of which will aim to display the science being conducted to enhance ecosystem understanding and guide management decision-making.This special issue centers on watershed, nutrient, microbial (including cyanobacteria), algal, and dreissenid mussel dynamics, including their causes and consequences. Specifically, it focuses on understanding factors that have driven changes in: 1) nutrient loading and in-lake nutrient dynamics; 2) algal and cyanobacteria dynamics; and 3) dreissenid growth, impacts, and spatial variation. After recapping each paper's major messages and management implications, we offer some concluding remarks.Since the early 2000s, Lake Erie has shown signs of intensified eutrophication, including increases in the extent and duration of hypoxia and harmful algal blooms dominated by cyanobacteria (hereafter, cyanoHABs; Scavia et al., 2014; Watson et al., 2016). Some of those symptoms have been linked to altered nutrient dynamics in Lake Erie's watersheds and, particularly, significant increases in dissolved reactive phosphorus loads (Baker et al., 2014; Stumpf et al., 2016). The source of most phosphorus entering Lake Erie is agriculture (Wilson et al., 2018); however, this source is dispersed across the landscape (Kast et al., 2021) and difficult to mitigate. Thus, delineating the characteristics of watersheds that export the largest amount of nutrients is important to identifying locations where nutrient reduction will be most effective. While reducing nutrient input is critical, the behavior of nutrients once they have entered the lake is likely to influence where and when cyanoHABs occur. Toward improving our understanding of eutrophication, two of this AEHM special issue's contributors focused on identifying causes of variation in the dynamics of nutrient loading and approaches to model the availability of these loads on chemicophysical conditions.Johnson et al. (2023) sought to identify how watershed characteristics have influenced nutrient and sediment inputs into western Lake Erie. To this end, these authors used a suite of physical attributes, land uses, and point-source contributions to characterize seven tributary watersheds, six of which are Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement Annex 4 priority watersheds, and five sub-watersheds. The authors then used principal components regression analysis to determine their relationship with nutrient and sediment yields into Lake Erie. Briefly, their results demonstrated spatial (regional) variation in contributions of nutrients and sediments from each river during 2017-2021 that was related to watershed attributes. For example, nutrient inputs into Lake Erie from watersheds were positively related to the percentage of land supporting cultivated crops and poorly drained soils, with higher slopes and lower amounts of pasture being positively correlated with sediment yields. These authors then discussed their findings in the context of impending nutrient reductions aimed at mitigation of Lake Erie's recent re-eutrophication (Baker et al., 2019), explaining how consideration of regional differences in nutrient and sediment yields could benefit nutrient management planning.While Johnson et al. centered on factors that influence nutrient and sediment loading into Lake Erie, Bocaniov et al. (2023) focused how nutrient (total phosphorus, TP) inputs affect within-lake TP movement and distribution. These authors used an updated phosphorus mass-balance model (2003-2016) to derive TP load-response relationships and response matrices to predict steady-state lake TP concentrations as a function of variable external TP inputs. A key finding is that inter-basin transfer of TP plays a large role in driving basin-specific TP concentrations (e.g. inflow from the central basin contributes ∼70% of the resident TP in the eastern basin). Bocaniov et al.'s modeling also demonstrated that western Lake Erie is likely to respond quickly (93 days) to reduced TP inputs, with longer response times estimated in the central and eastern basins (540 and 303 days, respectively). These authors then discuss how their findings can help guide where in the watershed to manage nutrients and what timeframes may be needed before agencies can expect to see impacts of nutrient abatement efforts.An outcome of excessive agricultural nutrient loading into aquatic ecosystems is enhanced primary production. Lake Erie has experienced increases in benthic algae (e.g. Cladophora), pelagic algae, and cyanobacteria during both past (1960s-1970s) and more recent eutrophication events (Munawar and Munawar, 1996; O'Donnell et al., 2023; Vollenweider et al., 1974; Watson et al., 2016). Lake Erie is a large and complex ecosystem, however, and the specific type or location of algal blooms cannot be predicted by nutrient loading alone. Rather, how and where blooms form will depend on complex processes such as gazing pressure and nutrient availability within the lake, as well as water warming that will interact with high nutrient availability. With this backdrop, four papers in this AEHM special issue sought to enhance our ability to understand and describe the dynamics of primary producers, including algae and cyanobacteria.To help better understand the mechanisms responsible for benthic Cladophora outbreaks in eastern Lake Erie since dreissenid mussels colonized the lake, Depew et al. (2023) quantified the enzymatically hydrolysable portion (EHP) of dissolved organic phosphorus (DOP). Samples were collected during May through September 2019 at varying depths along the north shore of the eastern basin. These authors found that the EHP substantially contributed to the dissolved P pool, with this contribution averaging 53% of the total dissolved P and 63% of the DOP concentration. Hence, a large amount of DOP appears bioavailable owing to enzymatic hydrolysis. This result, combined with the fact that bioavailable DOP concentrations often exceeded dissolved reactive P concentrations, indicates an increased role of the benthic contributions to P bioavailability in the eastern basin since the establishment of dreissenid mussels. In turn, Depew et al. highlight the need to consider EHP when designing management strategies to control Cladophora outbreaks in the eastern basin.In contrast to Depew et al., Hoffman et al. (2023) quantified seasonal nitrification in Lake Erie's water column and explored its potential role in driving microbial dynamics, including cyanoHABs dominated by Microcystis spp. To do so, these authors used the stable isotope, 15NH4+, to track nitrification and qPCR to determine the relative abundances of ammonia oxidizing organisms (i.e. bacteria and Archaea, AOO) during 2015-2017. Hoffman et al. found that nitrification rates were lower during cyanoHABs, suggesting that AOOs were not good competitors with cyanobacteria for ammonia. These low rates can in part explain why cyanoHABs dominated by Microcystis spp. (non-nitrogen fixers) can persist despite low bioavailable nitrogen (N). Further, the removal of bioavailable N via coupled nitrification-denitrification is lower than the increase in bioavailable N through regeneration and external N loading. Using these findings, Hoffman et al. discuss the importance of reducing N loading into Lake Erie as a means to help reduce seasonal cyanoHABs.Hounshell et al. (2023) also focused on understanding cyanoHAB dynamics, exploring the role of P as a driver instead of N. While total bioavailable P (TBP) loading from the Maumee River (Ohio, USA) during spring has been shown to be a strong predictor of cyanoHAB severity in western Lake Erie (Baker et al., 2014; Bertani et al., 2016; Stumpf et al., 2016), much unexplained variation in cyanoHAB severity remains. Thus, Hounshell et al. (2023) sought to identify environmental variables that could improve the predictive relationship between the Maumee River spring TBP load and cyanoHAB severity. Their modeling showed that at both low (< 273 MTA) and high (> 332 MTA) TBP loads levels, no other environmental factors improved predictive accuracy of cyanoHABs in western Lake Erie. However, during years with intermediate springtime TBP loads (273-332 MTA), predictions of cyanoHABs could be improved by considering winter and July TBP loads, as well as ice extent and phenology. While their work is still ongoing, Hounshell et al.'s research highlights the value of both tributary and in-lake monitoring, as well as process-based modeling to cyanoHAB forecasting.Wang et al. (2023) also sought to use modeling to predict the distribution of cyanoHABs in Lake Erie. Specifically, these authors compared the performance of the one-dimensional (1D) Aquatic Ecosystem Dynamics–General Lake Model (AED–GLM) and the three-dimensional (3D) Aquatic Ecosystem Model (AEM3D–iWQ) in predicting cyanoHABs, phytoplankton biomass (as measured by chlorophyll a), and associated physicochemical conditions (e.g. water temperature, nutrients), among other things, in western Lake Erie during 2008 and 2011-2014. By qualitatively comparing their results to in situ observations, Wang et al. showed that the 3D model better reproduced seasonal and spatial variation in nutrients and phytoplankton with less error than the 1D model. Conversely, cyanoHABs were better predicted by the 1D model. As detailed in their paper, Wang et al. explain how the scale at which these models are calibrated can drive differences in model performance. These authors also discuss the implications of their findings for choosing the appropriate model to support management endeavors, including how to best calibrate them to achieve desired goals.The final set of papers centered on invasive dreissenid mussels, which have become a ubiquitous part of the Great Lakes since their introduction nearly four decades ago (Nalepa et al., 2005). Owing to their potential to negatively impact native mussels (Schloesser et al., 2006), zooplankton communities (Johannsson et al., 2000), phytoplankton biomass (Bocaniov et al., 2014), and nutrient cycling (Hecky et al., 2004), Zebra (Dreissena polymorpha) and Quagga (D. rostiformis bugensis) Mussels have garnered the interest of researchers and management agencies alike. Much of this effort has been devoted to understanding the mechanisms that influence dreissenid demographics and impacts of the food web, which are the focus of the last set of papers in this AEHM special issue.To understand the growth dynamics of dreissenid mussels and their impact on phytoplankton in western Lake Erie, Carter et al. (2023) combined field surveys, in situ growth experiments, and laboratory excretion and grazing experiments. Their results, which are important in interpreting two of the remaining AEHM special issue papers, showed that dreissenid communities have lower clearance rates and excretion rates compared to previously reported rates. This understanding, combined with reduced dreissenid densities in Lake Erie during recent decades, led Carter et al. to conclude that the ability of dreissenids to compound the effect of eutrophication that causes cyanoHABs may be less than previously thought (e.g. Vanderploeg et al., 2009; but see Carrick et al., 2023 and Vanderploeg et al., 2023). Carter et al. (2023) acknowledge, however, that the impact of dreissenids could be locally high at times, owing to their patchy distribution across the basin. In turn, these authors stress the need for frequent, fine-scale benthic surveys, which could improve ability to understand and forecast the impacts of dreissenids on the ecosystem.Carrick et al. (2023) also sought to quantify the impact of dreissenid mussels on plankton assemblages (heterotrophs and phototrophs) in western Lake Erie. Using controlled experiments conducted monthly during May through October 2018, these authors show that dreissenids graze actively throughout the growing season, consuming nano-sized heterotrophic and phototrophic plankton (e.g. phototrophic cryptophytes, centric diatoms, and non-pigmented chrysomonads). By contrast, lower clearance rates of cyanobacteria (e.g. Microcystis spp.), dinoflagellates, and some colonial chlorophytes were observed. Carrick et al. further suggest that selective dreissenid grazing on "non-harmful" plankton species in the nanoplankton size range, combined with lower grazing rates on larger cyanobacteria and chlorophyte species, could contribute to western Lake Erie's cyanoHAB problem. Notably, the small-scale experimental results of Carrick et al. contrast those from Carter et al.'s (2023) field-based study. This discrepancy highlights the value of both experimental and field-based approaches, as well as the need to carefully consider the spatiotemporal context of the investigation, when to quantifying the role of dreissenid grazing as a secondary promoter (above nutrient loading) of cyanoHABs.Vanderploeg et al. (2023) also used an experimental approach to quantity the impacts of dreissenid mussel grazing on the phytoplankton community. Their experiments showed that grazing pressure on phytoplankton varied during May through October, with grazing on cryptophytes and diatoms being high during late May through early July. Despite cyanophytes dominating the phytoplankton beginning in late July, dreissenid grazing on them was non-existent or low. Interestingly, 16S rRNA gene-sequencing analyses showed a diverse cyanobacteria community with Planktothrix dominating during the spring and Cyanobium dominating most of the summer through fall. By contrast, Microcystis, which is largely thought to dominate cyanoHABs in Lake Erie, only dominated during late June. Further, Microcystis was preferentially rejected by Quagga Mussels relative to other cyanobacteria. Using these findings, Vanderploeg et al. draw a similar conclusion as Carrick et al. (2023) by suggesting that dreissenid grazing can favor specific cyanobacteria such as Microcystis. Importantly, however, the final effect of dreissenid grazing as a secondary promoter of cyanoHABS depends on the population density of dreissenids, which is currently low (Carter et al., 2023).In this special issue's final paper, Elgin et al. (2023) conducted an in situ study to quantify spatial variation in colonization potential, growth rates, and abundance of dreissenid mussels at two sites with contrasting water-column conditions in western Lake Erie. Despite finding comparable dreissenid colonization potential and growth between study sites, both on and in the experimental cages, Elgin et al. found fewer mussels in the surrounding sediment at the site nearer the Maumee River. These authors use this finding to conclude that water-column conditions appear to favor dreissenid settlement and growth on hard surfaces suspended above the substrate across the western basin, but that conditions on or near the substrate may inhibit mussel settling and growth. Elgin et al. eventually discuss how substrate-driven bottlenecks could inform our understanding of dreissenid recruitment and distribution, as well as nutrient dynamics, in western Lake Erie. These authors also suggest how better characterization of substrate conditions could support dreissenid control efforts.Owing to the impact of humans, the world's ecosystems have been experiencing dramatic change, which has threatened their structure, function, and dynamics, as well as their capacity to support services valued by society. The world's Great Lakes are no exception with these ecosystems being degraded by numerous anthropogenic stressors, including nutrient alteration (both eutrophication and oligotrophication), non-native species invasions, habitat destruction, and climate change, among many others (Allan et al., 2013; Jenny, 2020; Odada et al., 2003). The magnitude, multitude, and simultaneous nature of these stressors have in turn challenged both researchers seeking to understand the dynamics of these ecosystems and agencies charged with managing the valued natural resources (e.g. fish, wildlife) and other services (e.g. safe drinking water, recreational opportunities) that these ecosystems provide (Allan et al., 2013; Odada and Olago, 2006; Sterner et al., 2017). Such challenges highlight the need for continued research aimed at understanding the causes and consequences of anthropogenic change.While all the large lakes of the world have been altered by anthropogenic stress, Lake Erie is among the most degraded. Its susceptibility to anthropogenic stress is largely due to its small size, shallow depth, high connectivity via shipping, and large watershed that supports both large cities and agricultural production (Fraker et al, 2022; Ludsin et al., 2001; Reutter, 2019). Most relevant to this AEHM special issue, Lake Erie has shifted trophic states multiple times in response to human impacts and subsequent mitigation efforts. Prior to the 1950s, Lake Erie was primarily in a pre-industrial state of mesotrophy-oligotrophy and shifted to a state of hypertrophy-mesotrophy during the 1960s-1970s. During the 1980s-1990s, it shifted back to more mesotrophic conditions in response to both mitigation efforts designed to reduce point-source inputs of TP and the invasion of dreissenid mussels. Most recently (post 2000), Lake Erie returned to a more eutrophic state due to non-point source runoff of dissolved reactive phosphorus (Kane et al., 2014; Ludsin et al., 2001; Sinclair et al., 2023; Vollenweider et al., 1974). Concomitantly, Lake Erie has currently been experiencing increases in the magnitude and extent of both bottom hypoxia and cyanoHABs (Scavia et al., 2014; Watson et al., 2016), which are threatening: human health through cyanotoxin exposure (e.g. Francy et al., 2016; Wituszynski et al., 2017); fish populations and the fisheries that they support (e.g. Stone et al., 2020; Wolf et al., 2017); and the regional economy through effects on tourism and property values (Smith et al., 2019; Wolf et al., 2022). These threats have increased the need for the science necessary to make informed management decisions (Fraker et al., 2023; Fussell et al., 2016; Sterner et al., 2017; Scavia et al., 2023), which includes describing the current state of the Lake Erie ecosystem and understanding the causal mechanisms of recent ecosystem change.The contributions to this AEHM special issue have provided new insights into the drivers of nutrient inputs, in-lake nutrient concentrations, benthic algae (Cladophora), planktonic heterotrophs, microbial autotrophs (including cyanobacteria responsible for cyanoHABs), algae (e.g. diatoms, cryptophytes), and dreissenid mussels. Further, each study has provided information that could benefit management, whether it be ecological understanding that could support ecosystem modeling (e.g. quantifying dreissenid distributions and their impacts on grazing rates and nutrient excretion; Carter et al., 2023; Elgin et al., 2023) or tools that could support nutrient management decision-making (e.g. Bocaniov et al., 2023; Johnson et al, 2023), cyanoHAB severity (e.g. Carrick et al.,. 2023; Hounshell et al., 2023; Vanderploeg et al., 2023) or chemicophysical conditions, including algal and cyanobacteria biomass (e.g. Depew et al., 2023; Hoffman et al., 2023; Wang et al., 2023). While many additional messages can be found in the papers, collectively, three key conclusions can be made. First, findings from each of the three focal areas of this AEHM special issue highlight the need to consider fine spatial and/or temporal scales in both the watershed and the lake proper. Doing so offers a means to fully appreciate the complex array of processes driving the dynamics of Lake Erie's chemicophysical conditions and lower food web (e.g. primary producers, dreissenid mussels). Second, while the papers in this special issue showed the value of field-, laboratory-, and modeling-based research to describing, understanding, or predicting ecosystem conditions, they also pointed to challenges that can arise when integrating findings. For example, discrepancies can arise owing to studies being conducted in different settings (e.g. in the laboratory vs. in the field) or at different spatiotemporal scales (e.g. see Carrick et al., 2023; Carter et al., 2023; Vanderploeg et al., 2023). Finally, most papers demonstrated the need for continued and intensified monitoring (e.g. broader coverage at finer spatial and temporal scales), which will challenge agencies responsible for tracking ecosystem conditions. We expect, however, that continued improvement in our ability to cost-effectively monitor Lake Erie and its watershed via remote sensing technologies (Yang et al., 2022; Yin et al., 2021), combined with continually improving data-analytic approaches (e.g. machine and deep learning; Sun and Scanlon, 2019), will help agencies meet this challenge.While the research described in this AEHM special issue has addressed many knowledge gaps, many more remain. Our hope is that continued reporting of findings as part of this AEHM Ecology of Lake Erie series will increase our ability to understand and model the structure, function, and dynamics of the ecosystem. Such understanding and tools should facilitate our continued movement towards ecosystem-based management in the Great Lakes, which could help agencies rehabilitate the lake and sustainably manage its valued resources in the face of continued anthropogenic stress.We thank Ken Minns for providing helpful feedback on a previous version of this synthesis.

title: 2023: A year of success in the climate change battle or a missed opportunity?
abstract: From 30 November to 12 December 2023, the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) 28th Conference of the Parties (COP28) was held in the United Arab Emirates. This World Climate Action Summit brought together 154 Heads of State and Government. In the very final stage of the Summit, the Parties reached several important agreements including operationalization of the loss and damage fund reinforcing the role of children and youth as agents of change through the Presidency youth climate champion, to operationalizing the transition from the fossil fuel use, emissions cuts, and scaled-up financing arrangements (United Nations COP 28, 2024). According to many observers and commentators, the agreements, which aim at more decisive climate action before the end of the decade to keep the global temperature limit of 1.5°C, imply recognition that global greenhouse gas emissions need to be cut 43% by 2030, compared to 2019 levels, to achieve that goal. This includes accelerating efforts towards the phase-down of unabated coal power, phasing out inefficient fossil fuel subsidies, and other measures that drive the transition away from fossil fuels in energy systems. The direction towards more equitable development, with developed countries continuing to take the lead, is suggested as the path to achieving those ambitious goals, and if possible, closer to 2025 (1 year from now!). Other researchers note that the urgent phasing out of fossil fuels is necessary but not sufficient. Mazzucato et al. (2023) consider that even if we could decarbonize the economy tomorrow, we would still not have a sustainable future until we take steps to maintain water systems and natural habitats.
